greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = sum of the distinct values making up the exponents in the prime-factorization of n.
comment: a(n) = A088529(n) = A181591(n) for n: 2 <= n < 24. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 01 2010
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537 (terms 1..1000 from Diana Mecum)
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
example: 120 = 2^3 * 3^1 * 5^1. The exponents of the prime factorization are therefore 3,1,1. The distinct values which equal these exponents are 1 and 3. So a(120) = 1+3 = 4.
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Jan 07 2008
ext: More terms from _Diana L. Mecum_, Jul 17 2008
